snippet.textDisplay: The cliff-side scenery in the middle of night, the focus of the sword etched at the edge of the cliff, the vast landscape, the glistening ocean, the blinking stars, the asteroid/comet moving across the screen and lastly the title and story of the game appearing during the tones of this song. So nostalgic.

So nostalgic.

snippet.textDisplay: Same. More challenging. Maybe not as ground breaking or classic so to speak but it's a decent side scroller that feels very rewarding when you master it. Jumping at those shield knights with perfectly timed flying crouch mid level body strikes of force with the sword repeatedly which makes their shield useless is the most satisfying move ever.
snippet.textOriginal: Same. More challenging. Maybe not as ground breaking or classic so to speak but it's a decent side scroller that feels very rewarding when you master it. snippet.textDisplay: ah the memories. this game came with our used nes at a yardsale and the battery was dead so we couldnt save any progress if it was powered off. on top of that, our parents never let us play more than a couple hours at a time, and insisted on us turning the system off. despite this, we were pretty determined and basically got in the habit of speed running whatever we'd already figured out. one day, a glitch caused a bugged save file to appear that had the hammer and a weird random assortment of other items unlocked. this allowed us to bypass a large section that we'd really been struggling with and we were determined not to miss out on this opportunity. me and my brothers conspired to keep the game on for probably a week or two, at least, as we tried to complete the game, convincing our parents that the system was turned off by blocking the light with something and disconnecting the video cables. unfortunately our plot was eventually foiled by a power flash during a bad storm. we never got that bugged save file to appear again and we never did beat the game. lol, it all seams so ridiculous now :D (but i did eventually go back and beat the game a few years ago on an emulator)
snippet.textOriginal: ah the memories. this game came with our used nes at a yardsale and the battery was dead so we couldnt save any progress if it was powered off. on top of that, our parents never let us play more than a couple hours at a time, and insisted on us turning the system off. despite this, we were pretty determined and basically got in the habit of speed running whatever we'd already figured out. one day, a glitch caused a bugged save file to appear that had the hammer and a weird random assortment of other items unlocked. this allowed us to bypass a large section that we'd really been struggling with and we were determined not to miss out on this opportunity. me and my brothers conspired to keep the game on for probably a week or two, at least, as we tried to complete the game, convincing our parents that the system was turned off by blocking the light with something and disconnecting the video cables. unfortunately our plot was eventually foiled by a power flash during a bad storm. we never got that bugged save file to appear again and we never did beat the game. lol, it all seams so ridiculous now :D (but i did eventually go back and beat the game a few years ago on an emulator)

Needless to say I think we all had a headache at the end of the day only difference was was that i had a smile on my face great times.

snippet.textDisplay: This was my parents' favorite Zelda game so I grew up knowing every little bit of it.  I have to say, this brings me back to my very earliest childhood memories.  I beat the game again 10 years ago during a college spring break vacation at my parents' house.
snippet.textOriginal: This was my parents' favorite Zelda game so I grew up knowing every little bit of it.  I have to say, this brings me back to my very earliest childhood memories.  I beat the game again 10 years ago during a college spring break vacation at my parents' house.

snippet.textDisplay:
After Ganon was destroyed,
Impa told Link a sleeping
spell was cast on Princess
Zelda. She will wake only
with the power of No. 3
Triforce sealed in a palace
in Hyrule. To break the
seal, crystals must be
placed in statues in 6
well guarded palaces.
Link set out on his most
adventuresome quest yet...
1987 Nintendo﻿
snippet.textOriginal:
After Ganon was destroyed,
Impa told Link a sleeping
spell was cast on Princess
Zelda. She will wake only
with the power of No. 3
Triforce sealed in a palace
in Hyrule. To break the
seal, crystals must be
placed in statues in 6
well guarded palaces.
Link set out on his most
adventuresome quest yet...
1987 Nintendo﻿

snippet.textDisplay:
I just watched a video about the history of this theme song. Apparently the title theme originally was not going to be an original piece, but a piece from a composer (idk if that's the word) from many years ago. Non-original pieces only become available for public use in Japan 50 years after the  creator dies. Koji Kondo assumed 50 years had pieced as it was so old, but only 49 years had passed... He figured this out so last minute that he composed this theme song in one night by pulling an all nighter.


Edit: Nope I'm dumb
snippet.textOriginal:
I just watched a video about the history of this theme song. Apparently the title theme originally was not going to be an original piece, but a piece from a composer (idk if that's the word) from many years ago. Non-original pieces only become available for public use in Japan 50 years after the  creator dies. Koji Kondo assumed 50 years had pieced as it was so old, but only 49 years had passed... He figured this out so last minute that he composed this theme song in one night by pulling an all nighter.


Edit: Nope I'm dumb

snippet.textDisplay: Me too. It's just one of those games that you hate at first but once you git gud and learn how to jump/front stab while coming down on enemies like the knights it gets a lot easier and is always satisfying to pull off. Skillful as well. And seeing how those assholes are pretty much the most common tough enemy to fight it's a valuable skill to master. Once you do that the game feels a lot better.
snippet.textOriginal: Me too. It's just one of those games that you hate at first but once you git gud and learn how to jump/front stab while coming down on enemies like the knights it gets a lot easier and is always satisfying to pull off. snippet.textDisplay: Not really a blemish considering that there were only two games at the time, this and the original.  More like differently colored half.  In an alternate universe Miyamoto and his crew expand the Zelda universe from Zelda 2, making it more like an action RPG, instead of the item-finding Indiana Jones/James Bond/Batman Zelda we have today.  A Link to the Past and Link's Awakening solidified the series as an item-based romp, not an ability based adventure.
snippet.textOriginal: Not really a blemish considering that there were only two games at the time, this and the original.  More like differently colored half.  In an alternate universe Miyamoto and his crew expand the Zelda universe from Zelda 2, making it more like an action RPG, instead of the item-finding Indiana Jones/James Bond/Batman Zelda we have today.  A Link to the Past and Link's Awakening solidified the series as an item-based romp, not an ability based adventure.

snippet.textDisplay: Yep.  The masks are great, I especially like shape-shifting ones.  I really don't think there has been a bad Zelda (CD-I games don't exist...), however I am having troubles getting into Skyward Sword with the motion controls (seems like a great game though).  Plus games like Skyrim go where Zelda should have gone, and did start to go with Zelda II.  Imagine a fully explorable Hyrule (not just the area under Death Mountain's shadow) in the format of Skyrim.  Now THAT would be a godlike Zelda.
snippet.textOriginal: Yep.  The masks are great, I especially like shape-shifting ones.  I really don't think there has been a bad Zelda (CD-I games don't exist...), however I am having troubles getting into Skyward Sword with the motion controls (seems like a great game though).  Plus games like Skyrim go where Zelda should have gone, and did start to go with Zelda II.  Imagine a fully explorable Hyrule (not just the area under Death Mountain's shadow) in the format of Skyrim.  Now THAT would be a godlike Zelda.

snippet.textDisplay:
00:34, So once again you've saved your countrymen from certain death
Your sleeping beauty is awake but watch out, morning breath
You will have more daring escapades, 
Challenges along the way
Maybe you will learn to play the flute some other day
But for now
Look buddy you saved the world
Yeah buddy you got the girl
You did really great! Celebrate, have a date, procreate, 
Link you win!
YEAAH!!!

snippet.textDisplay: A classic. While I don't think this game's as great as some others in this series, it holds quite a lot of nostalgia for me. A lot of memories of seeing my brother play this game and then me trying as well and getting my ass kicked. Once again, music played a big role and I've always been a fan of its darker feel.
snippet.textOriginal: A classic. While I don't think this game's as great as some others in this series, it holds quite a lot of nostalgia for me. A lot of memories of seeing my brother play this game and then me trying as well and getting my ass kicked. Once again, music played a big role and I've always been a fan of its darker feel.
